transcripts.text: It is Tuesday, September 8th.  I'm Sam Seder.
And I'm Lucy Steiner.  Which one of these stories will you be talking about today?

The general election is off with Kamala Harris and Mike Pence hosting dueling events in Battleground State of Wisconsin.  All the while, of course, the economic picture continues to get worse and worse for American workers.  Meanwhile, yet another massive Trump truck rally outside of Portland results in violence as videos show right-wing hate group members chasing down anti-fascist activists with bats and mace.  Lastly, graduate students at the University of Michigan announce a full-on strike to shut things down until the school agrees to their demands for more coronavirus protections.
You're listening to Majority.FM's AM Quickie, and these are the stories you need to know.

Labor Day is the unofficial start to the general election, as we're about two months away from voting.  So let's break down how the race is set up for the next week or so.  Kamala Harris and Mike Pence hosted dueling events in Wisconsin, which is likely to be a major battleground state again in 2020.  In 2016, Trump took the state by just under 1%, so it's almost certainly in play for both parties this year.  Last week, both Biden and Trump visited Kenosha.  the city that's been rocked by protests since the police shooting of Jacob Blake.  The top of both tickets will be in Pennsylvania this week, which is another major battleground.  Biden spoke in Harrisburg on Monday and will be returning Friday to mark the anniversary of 9-11 in Shanksville, where United Flight 93 crashed.  Trump's planning to head there, too, that day.  Here's what to look for.  Kamala Harris's appearance in Milwaukee in particular is geared at turning out voters because the Democrats have zeroed in on low urban turnout in the city in 2016, being a big part of Clinton's loss.  So while the Biden-Harris campaign may not be offering much more in the way of policy than Clinton, they're at least attempting to avoid some of her electoral strategic mistakes.  The president, meanwhile, spent most of Labor Day tweeting about everything from Trump boat parades to his denial of the Atlantic story that alleged he referred to dead U.S.  service members as, quote, losers.  The backdrop to all this is a steadily worsening economic picture.  Analysis by the Morning Consult showed that while some Americans have gotten back to work, those who are still unemployed face dismal prospects of getting another job.  To make matters worse, things in Washington aren't going well.  The New York Times reports that a wave of statewide budget cuts is starting to roll through the country in the absence of a new aid package making it through Congress.  Look out for both campaigns to try and harness that pain into electoral support over the next few weeks because, of course, that's how politics works in this country.  In Portland, yet another massive Trump truck rally convened in a suburb outside the city.  Some more aggressive right-wing supporters peeled off for a demonstration in Salem, Oregon, which quickly devolved into an on-foot mayhem as right-wing demonstrators affiliated with the Proud Boys and other militias or hate groups charged at left-wing protesters while the police simply looked on.  Video shot by journalists at the scene showed armed militia members and Trump supporters charging a group of anti-fascist counter-protesters.  overwhelming one of them with strikes from a bat.  A woman then maced the fallen activists who sat on the ground.  This kind of violence is typical for the running battles between Portland protesters and right-wing militias that have raged this entire summer.  But the police response in Salem on Monday evening was particularly telling.  According to a New York Times reporter on the scene, cops, quote, pled.  with right-wing groups to move their lines back to the designated area for their demonstration.  It did, however, make some arrests of right-wingers who singled out and attacked a counter-protester in the park, but largely refrained from deploying the same aggressive warlike tactics against the Proud Boys and militias that they've used for months now against Black Lives Matter protesters.  Things are still being sorted in Oregon as of this reading.  But remember, after the last Trump truck rally, one right-wing demonstrator was shot.  So keep an eye out for more incidents as the dust settles today.

Majority.fm's AM Quickie is fueled by JustCoffee.coop.  JustCoffee is a worker-owned coffee roaster based in Madison, Wisconsin that has sponsored the Majority Report for nearly a decade.  Check out their collection of fair trade roasts, including our own Majority Report blend.  And regardless of what you order, receive 10% off your order when you use the code MAJORITY at checkout.  And all shipping is free.  That's coupon code MAJORITY at JustCoffee.coop.

The University of Michigan's Graduate Employees Organization, a powerful on-campus union that represents more than 2,000 teacher assistants and researchers, voted on Monday to go on strike until that university changes its COVID-19 policies.  The graduate students' demands are for the right to work remotely, transparency in opening plans, and more money to be diverted from the university's security budget to its COVID planning.  79% of the union voted to authorize the strike.  GEO Secretary Amir Fleischman told the Michigan Daily that negotiations with the university had ground to a deadlock.  Quote, it's the feeling of our bargaining team that there was not much more progress to be made at the bargaining table.  That's why we feel it's necessary to resort to these tactics.  because the university has shown that it's not really been willing to compromise on a lot of these issues.  Graduate students are a powerful force on campus, as their labor is relied upon heavily to keep the everyday workings of the university classes running.  The union plans to picket in person and remotely.  The strike is technically a wildcat strike, as the union's contract and state law prevents public employees from striking.  But remember, there are no illegal strikes, just unsuccessful ones.
And now for some quicker quickies.

Quicker quickie.  Legal observer for Amnesty International was denied remote access to the beginnings of the Julian Assange trial this weekend, raising concerns from some press freedom advocates already worried about the ramifications of Assange's indictment and incarceration.  Assange is accused of violating the U.S.  Espionage Act and is currently in the trial phase of a hearing, which will determine if he is extradited to the U.S.  to face punishment there.  Jacob Blake has spoken publicly for the first time since being shot seven times by the Kenosha Police Department.  In a video uploaded by an activist who spoke to Blake in the hospital, Blake spoke about the nature of his injuries, saying, quote, Every 24 hours, it's pain.  It's nothing but pain.  It hurts to breathe.  It hurts to sleep.  It hurts to move from side to side.  It hurts to eat.  One of California's most recent destructive wildfires, the El Dorado fire in San Bernardino County, was caused by an explosive device at a gender reveal party.  This would be monumentally stupid even if it was the first time it's happened, which it's not.  Philippines President Rodrigo Duterte added another instance of callous despotism to his record on Monday by issuing a full pardon to Scott Pemberton, a U.S.  Marine convicted of murdering Jennifer Laude, transgender woman, 2014.  Local human rights groups called Duterte's pardon a, quote, despicable and shameless mockery of justice, servility to the imperialist interests of the United States.  Quicker.

That's all for the AM Quickie.  Join us today at noon.  We will be live with the majority report.  Author Kurt Anderson will be joining us.  Of course, you can catch this later as a podcast.  Thanks for listening.  Stay safe.
